Legal_Provision_Violated: Obligation to assess safety of internal flight alternative
Application_Facts: Mr. Garcia, a gay man, claimed persecution in Mexico and sought refugee protection in Canada based on fear of violence due to sexual orientation
Procedural_Issue: Board failed to analyze contradictory evidence on safety conditions for gay men in Mexico City
Evidence_Used: Recent reports indicating tolerance in Mexico City
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to consider 1998 report documenting violent crimes against gay men in Mexico City
Decision_Outcome: Refugee claim rejected based on safe internal flight alternative in Mexico City
Outcome: Judicial review allowed; decision set aside
Remedy_Sought: Redetermination of claim by a different panel
Decision_Rationale: Board's conclusion about safety in Mexico City was unreasonable due to omission of material evidence

Governing_Law: Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees
Canadian jurisprudence on refugee status determination
Application_Facts: Choovak had permanent resident status in Germany which expired; she claimed inability to return to Iran and fear of persecution in Germany
Residency_Compliance: Failed to maintain valid German residency; status allowed renewal but was not renewed
Procedural_Issue: CRDD failed to properly analyze claim against Germany
Insufficient consideration of renewability of German status
Jurisdictional_Issue: Focus on Iran despite primary claim rooted in conditions in Germany
Evidence_Used: Evidence of expired German permanent residency
Evidence of ability to renew residency in Germany
Minimal evidence regarding conditions in Iran
Evidentiary_Deficiency: CRDD ignored evidence that Choovak could renew German residency
Lack of analysis on enjoyment of basic rights in Germany
Decision_Outcome: CRDD granted refugee status based on fear of persecution in Iran
Outcome: Federal Court quashed the CRDD decision
Legal_Standard_Applied: Application of Article 1E of the Refugee Convention
Decision_Rationale: CRDD erred by not recognizing that Choovak retained rights akin to nationality in Germany through renewable residency, and improperly shifted focus to Iran when her claim centered on Germany

Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 96 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Application_Facts: Respondent was a Tamil passenger on the MV Sun Sea claiming fear of persecution
Procedural_Issue: RPD failed to provide sufficient legal rationale or factual findings linking social group to persecution
Evidence_Used: Passenger status on MV Sun Sea, claimed risk due to Tamil ethnicity
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of connection between social group and human rights or discrimination considerations
Relief_Sought: Recognition as a refugee based on persecution risk
Remedy_Sought: Reconsideration by a different RPD panel
Legal_Standard_Applied: Membership in a particular social group under section 96
Decision_Rationale: Failure to establish nexus between social group or political opinion and persecution with adequate legal and factual basis

Crimes.Crime_Name: Pre-removal risk assessment refusal
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the officer erred in assessing the applicant's risk of torture, death, or cruel treatment if returned to Pakistan
Crimes.Governing_Law: IRPA s.97
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Officer found insufficient evidence linking applicant's MQM-A membership to specific risks; claims were vague and lacked detail
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate personalized risk
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Lack of credible, detailed evidence about threats or political involvement
Crimes.Legal_Rule: A person in need of protection must face a personal risk not shared by others in their country under IRPA s.97
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Risk of torture, death, or cruel treatment upon return to Pakistan due to MQM-A affiliation
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Applicant's membership in MQM-A, alleged attack by MQM-H, resulting paraplegia, lack of documentation on direct threats
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Officer concluded no sufficient link between applicant’s activities and personal risk
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Self-reported political involvement, medical records (paraplegia), lack of third-party verification
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Stay of removal based on risk of harm
Crimes.Authority: Immigration officer, reviewed by Federal Court

Crimes.Crime_Name: Breach of consent requirements under PIPEDA
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Privacy dispute involving unauthorized disclosure of personal information
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the applicant can claim damages under PIPEDA for unauthorized disclosure of personal information
Crimes.Governing_Law: Personal Information Protection and Electronic Documents Act (PIPEDA)
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Federal Court application for damages following investigation by Privacy Commissioner
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Bank disclosed personal account information without consent; applicant concealed information during divorce proceedings
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Damages awarded but reduced due to contributory fault
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: Applicant demonstrated breach of PIPEDA; bank failed to justify disclosure without consent
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Applicant's concealment of financial information affected credibility and contributed to harm
Crimes.Legal_Rule: PIPEDA requires consent for disclosure of personal information; courts may award damages for humiliation under Section 16(c)
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness and correctness in interpreting statutory obligations under PIPEDA
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Unauthorized disclosure of personal information in violation of PIPEDA Section 16(c)
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Claim upheld in part; breach confirmed but damages reduced
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Internal bank policies requiring consent, Privacy Commissioner's report, divorce proceeding records
Crimes.Legal_Framework: PIPEDA, federal privacy law governing private-sector handling of personal information
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Disclosure occurred despite internal policies; no justification provided for lack of consent
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence, complaint records, investigation findings
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Monetary damages for humiliation and breach of privacy
Crimes.Authority: Office of the Privacy Commissioner of Canada, Federal Court of Canada

Crimes.Crime_Name: Unauthorized disclosure of personal information
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Privacy dispute involving unauthorized disclosure during divorce proceedings
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the applicant can claim damages under PIPEDA Sections 14 and 16(c) for unauthorized disclosure
Crimes.Governing_Law: Personal Information Protection and Electronic Documents Act (PIPEDA)
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Complaint to Privacy Commissioner followed by application for damages in Federal Court
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Bank employee disclosed account details without consent; applicant concealed assets in divorce
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Partial liability assigned to both parties; damages reduced accordingly
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: Applicant proved unauthorized disclosure; bank could not demonstrate lawful basis for release
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Applicant’s conduct in concealing accounts undermined full compensation
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Organizations must obtain consent before disclosing personal information; damages available for humiliation under Section 16(c)
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Correctness regarding statutory interpretation, reasonableness in factual findings
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Violation of PIPEDA principles on consent and confidentiality
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Breach established, but contributory negligence applied
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Privacy Commissioner's investigation report, bank records, court filings from divorce case
Crimes.Legal_Framework: PIPEDA compliance framework for handling personal information in commercial contexts
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Disclosure made without authorization; internal controls failed to prevent breach
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Administrative investigation findings, financial records, legal filings
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Compensation for emotional distress and invasion of privacy
Crimes.Outcome: Court ordered payment of $4,500 in damages
Crimes.Authority: Federal Court of Canada, Office of the Privacy Commissioner
